sourceDesc.p: Created from original research by members of CWRC/CSÉC unless otherwise noted.

div.head: IRELAND
div.p: I Relandisa folie vneuen & hilly and the higheft hilleshaue flanding lakes on the tops, It hath alfo many booges and quagmyers & is generally watry woodie, & moorifh, yet hath it notwithftanding in diners places mofte faire plaines, which yet are but few in refpe & of the woodes. It is a fat foile, & apt to bring forte corne. The hillies abound with carrel, and the woodes with wyld beaftes. This lle is more plentiful of pafture then of corne, of gras then of graine yea the wheat-corne is fmall & withered, and not oafy to beewynoed with a fan. In tyme of barueft the raine fearfly permitteth the corne to bee gotten into the barne, fomnuch is this lle fubiect vnto raine. It is plentifull of milk & hony. Solinus and Ifidorus affirme it to haue no bees, but they might more truly haue written the contrary. No toade, adder, fpider or venemous beaft is no wrifhed in this countrie, nor can liue therein beeing broought thether from any other place.
